edu.biu.scapi.interactiveMidProtocols.coinTossing
Class CTBlumPartyOne

java.lang.Object
  edu.biu.scapi.interactiveMidProtocols.coinTossing.CTBlumPartyOne
All Implemented Interfaces:
CTPartyOne, Covert, Malicious, OneSidedSimulation, ProtocolSecLevel, SecurityLevel, SemiHonest, StandAlone
public class CTBlumPartyOne
extends java.lang.Object
implements CTPartyOne, StandAlone, Malicious

This class plays as party one of coin tossing Blum protocol, which tosses a single bit.

This protocol is fully secure under the stand-alone simulation-based definitions.

For more information see M. Blum. Coin Flipping by Phone. IEEE COMPCOM, 1982.

The pseudo code of this protocol can be found in Protocol 6.1 of pseudo codes document at http://crypto.biu.ac.il/scapi/SDK_Pseudocode_SCAPI_V2.0.0.pdf.

Author:
Cryptography and Computer Security Research Group Department of Computer Science Bar-Ilan University (Moriya Farbstein)

Method Summary
 CTOutput toss()
          Execute the following protocol: "SAMPLE a random bit b1 <- {0,1} RUN sub protocol COMMIT.commit on b1 WAIT for a bit b2 from P2 RUN sub protocol COMMIT.decommit to reveal b1 OUTPUT b1 XOR b2."

Method Detail

toss

public CTOutput toss()
              throws java.io.IOException,
                     CommitValueException,
                     CheatAttemptException,
                     java.lang.ClassNotFoundException
Execute the following protocol:

"SAMPLE a random bit b1 <- {0,1}

RUN sub protocol COMMIT.commit on b1

WAIT for a bit b2 from P2

RUN sub protocol COMMIT.decommit to reveal b1

OUTPUT b1 XOR b2."

Specified by:
toss in interface CTPartyOne
Returns:
CTOutput contains the tossed "coin".
Throws:
java.io.IOException - can occur in the commit phase.
CommitValueException - can occur in case the protocol uses an ElGamal committer.
CheatAttemptException - if party one suspects that party two is trying to cheat.
java.lang.ClassNotFoundException - if there was a problem in the serialization mechanism
